did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Seminary and College Dean of Students records
did.abstract: This collection contains student handbooks from Mount Vernon Seminary, Mount Vernon Junior College, and Mount Vernon College. They range in date from 1923 to 1998.
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains student handbooks from Mount Vernon Seminary, Mount Vernon Junior College, and Mount Vernon College. They range in date from 1923 to 1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In general, the Dean of Students oversees a wide range of student services including: administrative services, student health and wellness, academic support, career development, and leadership programs.

The Mount Vernon Seminary began in 1875 as a private high school and junior college for women, founded by Elizabeth J. Somers. The George Washington University initially affiliated with Mount Vernon College, and ultimately acquired the college's property and legacy in 1999.
The first school of higher education available to women in Washington, D.C., Mount Vernon Seminary and College had five different locations throughout its history:
1875-1880: Elizabeth Somers began tutoring the young daughters of prominent Washington men in her home at 204 F Street, NW in Washington, DC.
1880-1917: The school moved to 1100 M Street, NW where it expanded rapidly to include three additional houses, a courtyard, tennis court, and basketball court.

1917-1942: Having outgrown its M Street location, the school moved to a 15.5-acre campus on Nebraska Avenue, NW. The buildings and layout of the campus were designed by a New York architect, Wesley S. Bessell. and the campus was formally dedicated on November 5, 1917 -- Mrs. Somers' 80th birthday. In 1942, the United States Navy took over the Nebraska Avenue campus to use its facilities for the war effort.
1943-1946: The school resumed courses in February 1943 at the top floor of a Garfinckel's department store building in the Spring Valley neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

1946-1999: Between 1944 and 1946, the school built a new 21-acre campus located on Foxhall Road in Washington, D.C. using money granted to the college by the United States Navy in compensation for the military takeover of its property.

The last Seminary class graduated in 1969, and the school was then officially renamed to Mount Vernon Junior College. In 1976, Mount Vernon College became an accredited four year college. In 1997, the Board of Trustees decided that the College would close as an independent institution. As of June 30, 1999, Mount Vernon became affiliated with The George Washington University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Currently organized into one series: Student handbooks.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection is from Mount Vernon College, which The George Washington University acquired in 1999.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Seminary School handbooks, Junior College handbooks, and Mount Vernon College handbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include student handbooks from Mount Vernon Seminary, Mount Vernon Junior College, and Mount Vernon College. They range in date from 1923 to 1998.

The student handbooks from Mount Vernon Seminary, Junior College, and College contain a wide range of information including but not limited to: rules and regulations (dress code, acadmic honor code, code of conduct, daily schedules, visiting hours, judicial process, etc.), lists of clubs and activities, Mount Vernon traditions, important dates and phone number, and names of members of various student organizations.
Some handbooks also include messages of welcome from the school's president, photographs of current students, the alma mater, and drawings of the campus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this subseries include student handbooks from Mount Vernon Seminary. They range in date from 1923 to 1965.

did.unittitle: Summary of Rules and Regulations, MVS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this subseries include student handbooks from Mount Vernon Junior College. They range in date from 1934-1970.

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Junior College Student Handbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this subseries include student handbooks from Mount Vernon College. They range in date from 1970-1998.
